image.altText: A woman stands in front of a screen which has an image of a man holding a woman in water

items.synopsis: The 33-year-old was picked by a panel of judges for her performance-based video work Witness, which depicts her being repeatedly submerged in water.

title.children: SA artist Ida Sophia wins $100k Ramsay Art Prize

image.altText: Reporters point microphones at a man wearing a suit and a blue stripy shirt outside a stone building

items.synopsis: Phillip Andrew Callen had been a relief teacher at several South Australian primary schools including Belair, Burnside and Goodwood.

title.children: Primary school teacher charged with child sexual abuse has case against him dropped

image.altText: Police lights and a sign sitting on top of a police car

items.synopsis: SA Police say the woman's car crashed into a tree at Uleybury on Thursday night, making it the 54th death on South Australia's roads this year. A man is also reported over a crash at Rostrevor in Adelaide's east.

title.children: Woman killed after her car crashes into a tree north of Adelaide

image.altText: A wall collapses during a building fire in the Central Business District of Sydney.

items.synopsis: Fire crews worked throughout the night to mop up a blaze that destroyed a seven-storey heritage building in Sydney's inner city.

title.children: Two 13-year-olds have handed themselves in over 'once in a decade' fire that gutted a Sydney building

image.altText: A black and white historical photo of a young man wearing a suit

items.synopsis: Blond and boyish, Adelaide's Jimmy Melrose was an aviation sensation in his day, and achieved celebrity status by smashing records and flying solo to the UK. After he met his fate among the clouds, 100,000 people turned out to salute him.

title.children: This pilot prodigy flew to London on his own at 21 — then tragedy struck

image.altText: Marcus Stewart stands in a park, dressed in an Akubra and t-shirt bearing the message 'Always Was, Always Will Be'.

items.synopsis: The Uluru dialogue six years ago led to the Statement from the Heart and, ultimately, the upcoming referendum that could deliver constitutional change.

title.children: Voice campaigner calls for overhaul of national Indigenous agency on anniversary of Uluru statement

image.altText: Two Australian army infantry fighting vehicles.

items.synopsis: Lucrative construction work on new high-tech Army infantry fighting vehicles (IFVs) could be sent overseas under an option being considered by the Albanese government to acquire the lethal land capability more urgently.

title.children: Army's new infantry fighting vehicles could be built overseas to meet urgent strategic needs

image.altText: A tourniquet is applied to a woman's arm in preparation for a blood test, for a story about chickenpox and pregnancy

items.synopsis: The inquiry has recommended significant changes to Australia's health system for reproductive and sexual health care.

title.children: Accessible abortion, contraception incentives and Telehealth extensions: What a new report means for health care

image.altText: A close-up of an incandescent light-bulb with the word "POWER STRUGGLE" superimposed on it.

items.synopsis: Headline price increases of 25 per cent barely tell the story of struggling households at risk of falling behind in the energy transition.

title.children: Why price hikes are masking an energy divide that threatens to leave poor Australians behind

image.altText: Gorgeous kelpie in winter coat smiling

items.synopsis: Electricity prices are set to soar come July 1. Here's how you can save some money, while staying warm.

title.children: Energy prices are set to rise up to 25 per cent. Here's how you can save on bills heading into winter

image.altText: A tourist is silhouetted as he takes pictures of Mount Nuptse in the Everest region.

items.synopsis: Australian engineer Jason Kennison is the 10th climber to die on Mount Everest this spring in one of the deadliest climbing seasons in recent history.

title.children: Why have there been so many deaths on Mount Everest this climbing season?

image.altText: Multiple packets of colourful pharmaceutical medicines.

items.synopsis: The Pharmacy Guild of Australia says 400 drugs are on the "critical" shortage list and 20 per cent of those would be out of stock due to the government's new 60-day script policy. But the data tells a different story.

title.children: We fact checked the Pharmacy Guild's claims about medicine shortages. Here's what we found

image.altText: A woman standing in the dark staring off into the distance.

items.synopsis: At just two years old, Monica Wallabindi's mother was stolen from her family. She says National Sorry Day isn't about making anyone feel personally guilty or responsible, but acknowledging Australia's past.

title.children: Today is National Sorry Day, but many Indigenous Australians say they're still asked: 'Why should I apologise?'

image.altText: NSW Police and salvage personnel lift the body of the wreckage of a seaplane

items.synopsis: NSW Deputy State Coroner Derek Lee said it was "regrettable" carbon monoxide detection was not initially conducted post-mortem.

title.children: Sydney Seaplane crash that killed six people in 2017 likely caused by engine fumes, coroner finds

image.altText: A hand is pouring red wine from a decanter into a wine glass being held by another person

items.synopsis: A Coonawarra winemaker says while the recognition is nice, his product's job is "just to be delicious" rather than win awards.

title.children: Aussie wine with 'classic style' wins best cabernet sauvignon at International Wine Challenge

image.altText: Jason De Ieso was murdered in late 2012

items.synopsis: A Supreme Court murder trial hears a key witness saw a "black duffel bag" and "piles of guns" handed out at an Adelaide home before the fatal shooting of Jason De Ieso in November 2012.

title.children: Witness saw 'piles of guns' handed out before fatal shooting, murder trial told

image.altText: A nuclear power plant on a rocky shore

items.synopsis: Operators of the Fukushima nuclear power plant are set to release treated wastewater into the ocean. But already Japanese authorities are facing a barrage of criticism from fishermen.

title.children: Inside Japan's plan to release one million tonnes of water from its stricken nuclear plant

image.altText: A close-up shot of a First Nations woman with dyed red hair and glasses

items.synopsis: Victoria's Aboriginal treaty body calls on Facebook to better control racist abuse online, as it counters a surge of hate speech it fears is being fanned by the national debate on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament.

title.children: 'This shouldn't have to be my day job': Victorian treaty body overwhelmed by 'tidal wave' of racist abuse online

image.altText: Black and white photo of Gerd Heidemann standing, holding two large books, before group of men seated near microphones.

items.synopsis: In 1983 German magazine Stern thought it had a major scoop. It turned out to be a major hoax, and revealed a disturbing willingness to fall for a revised history of Hitler.

title.children: A forger tried to rewrite Hitler's history. Why did mainstream media fall for the hoax?

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt and a woman in a black shirt sit at a table smiling

items.synopsis: When he was diagnosed with lung cancer last year, Townsville resident Hugh Boon was given six months to live. Now, a clinical trial is giving him hope — but it comes at a "traumatic" travel cost.

title.children: 'Lucky' Hugh is in a cancer trial, but he must travel 1,300km to access it

image.altText: A wanted poster shows a group of men wanted, some have an ex through their pic.

items.synopsis: Fulgence Kayishema was living under a false name at a grape farm in South Africa when he was arrested for ordering the murder of thousands of Tutsis in Rwanda's 1994 genocide.

title.children: Former cop on Rwandan 'most wanted' list arrested over thousands of killings

image.altText: a man wearing dark glasses walking out of the forencic department

items.synopsis: As a coroner found Sydney fraudster Melissa Caddick is dead, she spoke about the "strong suspicion" of police that Anthony Koletti has withheld information from investigators.

title.children: The last person to see Melissa Caddick alive was a 'significant burden' to police investigation, coroner finds

image.altText: An F1 car in a show room, black at the front, white in the middle and orange at the back, on display.

items.synopsis: With a brand new look and a history of success around the famous track, Piastri is looking to impress during his first Monaco Grand Prix.

title.children: Australian Piastri to drive 'incredible'-looking car for first Monaco Grand Prix

image.altText: Specimens in a jar on a table.

items.synopsis: Scientists calculate there are thousands of unidentified species living on the ocean floor between Hawaii and Mexico where deep-sea mining for critical minerals needed to build batteries is set to begin next year.

title.children: Thousands of unidentified deep-sea species found in part of Pacific Ocean earmarked for mining

image.altText: A middle aged man is speaking into a microphone. He is dressed in black with a black eyepatch. He sticks one finger up.

items.synopsis: The founder of far-right militant group Oath Keepers, Stewart Rhodes, is sentenced to 18 years in prison for seditious conspiracy in a failed bid to keep Donald Trump in the White House.

title.children: Longest Capitol riot sentence yet: Oath Keepers founder gets sentenced to 18 years in prison

image.altText: Mr Albanese gestures with both hands raised while speaking from someone's backyard a clothesline barely visible behind him.

items.synopsis: The notions of "left" and "right" don't mean a lot in today's Labor, except as groupings to dole out preselections, frontbench representation and other spoils, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Does Labor still know its left from its right?

image.altText: A close up of a brown coloured rock wallaby.

items.synopsis: A breeding program to safeguard the future of the brush-tailed rock wallaby is expanding. Conservationists say it's like creating a safe "half-way house" for the endangered species.

title.children: The 'half-way house' trying to save 'incredible little wallaby' from extinction

image.altText: A man in a suit stands behind microphones in front of a colonnaded building entrance.

items.synopsis: The German economy was in recession in early 2023 after household spending in Europe's economic engine finally succumbed to the pressure of high inflation.

title.children: German economy enters recession as inflation hits consumers

image.altText: Black and white photo of Tina Turner and Ike Turner performing in 1965

items.synopsis: The superstar was open about how the trauma of her abusive marriage lingered long after she escaped her ex-husband, but she spoke honestly about it even up to her final weeks.

title.children: 'Fill your life with love': Tina Turner's last interviews reveal how she overcame abuse and built her legacy

image.altText: People walking in Brisbane's Queen Street Mall

items.synopsis: ASIC has ordered buy now, pay later provider Humm to stop signing new customers under an interim order, while NSW and Victoria enter a "retail recession" according to analysts. Follow live.

title.children: NSW and Victoria in a 'retail recession' as spending falls flat, Humm told to stop signing new customers, ASX rises

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Callam Pickering, Asia-Pacific economist at Indeed says the retail figures signal that NSW and Victoria are experiencing a "retail recession". He says the retail figures show momentum has ground to a halt as cost of living pressures keep building in the economy. "Given strong population growth and rising prices, it's clear that Australian households, on average, are consuming fewer retail products than they did last year," he said. "High cost-of-living, rising mortgage rates and the sharp decline in inflation-adjusted wages will make things difficult for the retail sector over the remainder of the year. That will be partially offset by high immigration and low unemployment. "We anticipate a considerable slowdown in household spending over the second half of the year." He says looking at state and territory figures, two of Australians biggest states are in a recession when it comes to retail. "Both New South Wales and Victoria are in a retail recession that began in the December quarter last year," he said. "By comparison, spending in South Australia is booming and reached a record level in April, following events such as the AFL Gather Round."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NSW, Victoria are experiencing a 'retail recession'

children.content: Callam Pickering, Asia-Pacific economist at Indeed says the retail figures signal that NSW and Victoria are experiencing a "retail recession".
He says the retail figures show momentum has ground to a halt as cost of living pressures keep building in the economy.
"Given strong population growth and rising prices, it's clear that Australian households, on average, are consuming fewer retail products than they did last year," he said.

"High cost-of-living, rising mortgage rates and the sharp decline in inflation-adjusted wages will make things difficult for the retail sector over the remainder of the year. That will be partially offset by high immigration and low unemployment.
"We anticipate a considerable slowdown in household spending over the second half of the year."
He says looking at state and territory figures, two of Australians biggest states are in a recession when it comes to retail.
"Both New South Wales and Victoria are in a retail recession that began in the December quarter last year," he said.
"By comparison, spending in South Australia is booming and reached a record level in April, following events such as the AFL Gather Round."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to Capital Economics, who say the weak retail sales just released from the ABS strengthen the argument that the Reserve Bank of Australia has finished its current rate hiking cycle. Marcel Thieliant from Capital Economics said the unchanged values were weaker than analysts had been expecting (which was a 0.2% rise). He says that even if there are modest monthly rises in retail spending in May and June, there are signs that consumer spending is "running out of steam". "What's more, April data point to a strong rise in vehicle sales this quarter. However, there are mounting signs that the recovery in services spending is running out of the steam, so overall consumer spending will remain sluggish this quarter ," he wrote. "Coupled with rising unemployment and lukewarm wage growth, that should prompt the Reserve Bank of Australia to keep interest rates unchanged over the coming months ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Weak retail figures suggest RBA is 'done hiking interest rates'

children.content: That's according to
Capital Economics
, who say the weak retail sales just released from the ABS strengthen the argument that the Reserve Bank of Australia has finished its current rate hiking cycle.
Marcel Thieliant from Capital Economics said the unchanged values were weaker than analysts had been expecting (which was a 0.2% rise).
He says that even if there are modest monthly rises in retail spending in May and June, there are signs that consumer spending is "running out of steam".

"What's more, April data point to a strong rise in vehicle sales this quarter. However, there are mounting signs that the recovery in services spending is running out of the steam, so overall consumer spending will
remain sluggish this quarter
," he wrote.
"Coupled with
rising unemployment
and
lukewarm wage growth,
that should prompt the Reserve Bank of Australia to
keep interest rates unchanged over the coming months

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're less than a fortnight away from the next RBA meeting, and what they will decide to do with the cash rate. But new analysis from the Commonwealth Bank suggests it's likely we won't see another rate rise. How likely? They're giving it a 90% chance of no change, and a 10% chance of a 0.25 percentage point increase (which would take the cash rate to 4.1%). CBA's head of economics Gareth Aird says there are a couple of reasons behind their thinking: "Another rate increase would require the economic data, particularly around inflation, GDP, the unemployment rate and wages/unit labour costs, to come in stronger than the RBA's updated forecasts. "Put another way, we do not think the RBA will lift the cash rate again if the economic data prints in line or weaker than their forecasts from the May Statement on Monetary Policy (SMP). "Since the May Board meeting the main economic data that will feed into policy deliberations at the June Board meeting has come in slightly weaker than the RBA's latest forecasts. "The 2023 May Commonwealth Budget has also been handed down since the May Board meeting. And our assessment is that it does not add to inflationary pressures in the economy. "The run of recent data coupled with our take on the Commonwealth Budget means at this juncture we do not think the June Board meeting is 'live'. " Of course, this is just a prediction — but CBA was the only one of the big four banks to correctly call the shock rise this month. (And while I'm talking about the RBA, we can expect to hear more about the bank's decisions and thinking when governor Philip Lowe appears at Senate Estimates next Wednesday...)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No change to interest rates at RBA's next meeting, Commonwealth Bank says

children.content: We're less than a fortnight away from the next RBA meeting, and what they will decide to do with the cash rate.
But new analysis from the Commonwealth Bank suggests it's likely we won't see another rate rise.
How likely? They're giving it a
90% chance of no change
, and a
10% chance of a 0.25 percentage point increase
(which would take the cash rate to 4.1%).
CBA's head of economics
Gareth Aird
says there are a couple of reasons behind their thinking:
"Another rate increase would require the economic data, particularly around inflation, GDP, the unemployment rate and wages/unit labour costs, to come in stronger than the RBA's updated forecasts.
"Put another way,
we do not think the RBA will lift the cash rate again
if the economic data prints in line or weaker than their forecasts from the May Statement on Monetary Policy (SMP).
"Since the May Board meeting the main economic data that will feed into policy deliberations at the June Board meeting has come in slightly weaker than the RBA's latest forecasts.
"The 2023 May Commonwealth Budget has also been handed down since the May Board meeting. And our assessment is that it does not add to inflationary pressures in the economy.
"The
run of recent data coupled with our take on the Commonwealth Budget means at this juncture we do not think the June Board meeting is 'live'.
Of course, this is just a prediction — but CBA was the only one of the big four banks to correctly call the shock rise this month.
(And while I'm talking about the RBA, we can expect to hear more about the bank's decisions and thinking when
governor Philip Lowe
appears at Senate Estimates next Wednesday...)

image.altText: An African American woman stands in a courtroom dock, looking worried. Two white policeman glance in her direction.

items.synopsis: Senegalese-French documentarian Alice Diop's debut narrative feature film is a thoughtful and complex examination of a bizarre, tragic case that caused a sensation across France.

title.children: Film about a child murder trial exposes the preciousness of love — and its devastating absence

image.altText: A Russian military officer walks past the 9M729 land-based cruise missile on display with its launcher

items.synopsis: Russia moves ahead with a plan to deploy tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus in the Kremlin's first deployment of such bombs outside Russia since the 1991 fall of the Soviet Union.

title.children: Russia moves ahead with deployment of tactical nuclear weapons in Belarus

image.altText: Luton Town fan with an orange and white hat on his face

items.synopsis: Luton Town and Coventry City are just one game away from completing miracle promotion campaigns to the riches of the English Premier League — which is why their play-off final is being hailed as "one for the romantics".

title.children: The remarkable recovery of two clubs from the brink of oblivion to within a game of the Premier League
